title: Timelash
dialogue_triumphs: The waves of time wash us all clean.
goofs: In the power room, Maylin Renis, whilst adjusting some control dials, pulls one of them off and hurriedly replaces it.
The Timelash is full of tinsel.

continuity_notes.name: Kontron tunnel
continuity_notes.description: A time corridor in space connecting Karfel to Earth in the 12th century near Inverness, Scotland.
continuity_notes.current_status: Active and used in the story

continuity_notes.name: Bendalypse warheads
continuity_notes.description: Gas weapons that kill anything with a central nervous system, but not effective against the reptilian Morlox.

continuity_notes.name: Mustakozene-80
continuity_notes.description: A chemical that produces mutation on contact with human skin.

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's time and space machine.

technobabble: You don't seem to realise the effect that time particles colliding within a multi-dimensional implosion field can have
roots: H. G. Wells' works: The Time Machine (the Morlox, Vena), War of the Worlds (the Bandril/Karfel war), The Invisible Man (the Doctor experiments with crystals), The Island of Doctor Moreau (transformation of men into animals)
Dune (Colin Baker's nod to the creator with the line 'To be perfectly frank, Herbert')
Close Encounters of the Third Kind (android's line 'Yes indeed she was' in the same pitch as the communication music)
links: Reference to 'Resurrection of the Daleks' when Peri asks about the Daleks' time corridor
Peri recognizes a photograph of Jo Grant, suggesting the Doctor showed her pictures of previous companions

locations.name: Karfel
locations.description: The main setting of the story, connected to Earth via the Kontron tunnel.
locations.current_status: Location of primary events in the episode

locations.name: Scotland, 1885
locations.description: Earth location connected to Karfel via the Kontron tunnel.

untold_adventures: An untelevised Third Doctor and Jo Grant adventure on Karfel where the Doctor saved the planet from an unspecified disaster and reported the scientist Magellan to the presidium for unethical experiments on the Morlox creatures
additional_notes: The episode features H. G. Wells as a character, giving him 'a story of his own' in the Doctor Who universe.
bottom_line: 'Timelash', like all good Doctor Who, has a beginning, a middle and an end. Unfortunately it's also got another end tacked on, seemingly with little thought as to believability. Tacky sets and some dodgy acting add up to a mess, although it's nowhere near as bad as its reputation.
